identification.role: Second-in-command to Brutus; strategic architect of Rome's operations; secondary antagonist
identification.time_period_active: ~30–40 CE (living); frozen at ~35 CE (cursed); active through final scene
identification.primary_narrative_function: Strategic architect of Rome's operations. The calculating mind behind Brutus' authority.

physical_description.build: Lean and athletic — less muscular than Brutus but stronger in appearance through posture and movement. Proportioned for endurance and calculated grace, not brute force.

distinctive_features.eyes: Dark eyes — nearly black — penetrating and calculating
distinctive_features.scars: Long scar along right ribcage (old sword wound). Nick along jawline (knife fight).
distinctive_features.face: Sharp cheekbones suggesting high Gallic ancestry. Raven symbol tattooed on left shoulder in black ink — personal, not standard military issue.

physical_description.typical_dress: Red centurion's cloak worn with more ease than Brutus. Bronze helmet. Leather cuirass. Hidden secondary blade (dagger) always present alongside standard sword. Silver raven brooch — personal symbol.
physical_description.bearing: Upright but fluid — more graceful than rigid. Moves with calculated purpose. Enters rooms with assessment rather than assertion. Less obviously commanding than Brutus, more quietly dangerous.
physical_description.voice: Slightly faster than Brutus. More ornate, more complex — uses subordinate clauses, rhetorical questions, historical precedent. Occasionally reveals slight Gallic lilt in pronunciation.

background_history.family_background: Born in Lugdunum (modern Lyon). Father was a Gallic warrior who allied with Rome — adopted Roman name, became Romanized. Corvus grew up between two identities, belonging fully to neither.
background_history.defining_childhood: Father's transition from Gallic warrior to Roman ally became Corvus' foundational model — adaptation grants status. Mother died when he was approximately eight. Early independence forced by circumstance.
background_history.education_training: Educated in both Gallic and Roman traditions. Tutored in Latin, Greek, and military science. Recognized as officer material early. Rapid advancement from age sixteen onward.
background_history.key_life_events: Age 18–24: military service in Gaul and Britannia; built reputation for strategic excellence. Age 24–28: promoted to centurion; served in multiple provinces. Age 28–32: transferred to Judea; became Brutus' second-in-command. The crucifixion is simply another order executed with strategic precision — until the curse begins.
background_history.turning_points: Meeting Brutus (found hierarchy worthy of his loyalty). The crucifixion (first sign that something is wrong with the world he has built himself inside).
background_history.current_circumstances: Commands Rome's strategic operations in Jerusalem as Brutus' second. Plans what Brutus executes.

primary.name: Brutus
primary.dynamic: Superior officer for five years. Entirely professional — Corvus is the intellect behind Brutus' authority, and both know it. Trusts Brutus will not yet recognize his ambition as a threat. After cursing, separation from Brutus is catastrophic.

primary.name: Malchus
primary.dynamic: Noticed early as intelligent — respects this. Professional collegiality shifts to suspicion as Malchus' response to the crucifixion marks him as different. Eventually becomes the central opposition.

primary.name: Rome (institution)
primary.dynamic: Loyalty is genuine but conditional — Rome provides the framework for advancement. If Rome ordered Corvus to betray Brutus, he would likely comply.

secondary.name: Maximus
secondary.dynamic: Unit leader under Corvus' command. Pedagogical relationship — Corvus teaches Maximus strategic thinking; Maximus implements with enthusiasm.

secondary.name: Horatius
secondary.dynamic: Soldier under Maximus. Largely invisible to Corvus — functional unit, receives direct orders, nothing more.

relationships.how_they_connect: Through intellectual respect. Corvus connects with those he finds intelligent or strategically useful. Contempt for the mediocre is consistent and barely concealed.
relationships.loyalty: Total to Rome — conditionally. Total to Brutus — until Rome provides reason otherwise. Total to self-advancement — always.

motivations.what_drives_them: Advancement through strategic excellence. The proof that a Romanized Gaul can surpass those born to Roman identity. Rome is the system he has chosen — he must make it reward that choice.
motivations.what_they_want_most: A position of command equal to or exceeding Brutus. Complete integration into Roman identity. The erasure of the Gallic heritage he cannot quite bury.
motivations.what_they_actually_need: What he cannot comprehend — to understand that his superior intelligence makes him more, not less, culpable. The curse does not care about his strategic reasoning.
motivations.short_term_goals: Execute the crucifixion detail with strategic excellence. Position himself as indispensable. Monitor Brutus' increasing instability as potential advancement opportunity.
motivations.long_term_ambitions: Tribune. Command in a larger province. Complete absorption into Roman identity.

story_arc.entry_state: Confident second-in-command at the height of his capability. Strategic mind in full operation. Watching Brutus closely. Watching Malchus with interest.
story_arc.what_they_believe: That he is the superior strategic mind in Jerusalem — perhaps in Judea. That Rome will eventually recognize this. That his Gallic birth is an obstacle he has overcome.
story_arc.main_problem: He does not yet know he has one beyond Brutus' rank above him. The crucifixion is a strategic operation. What follows will dismantle the framework he has built his entire identity inside.

character_journey.act_one: The crucifixion. Executed with strategic precision. Malchus' response noted and catalogued. Brutus' unease observed — assessed as potential opportunity. First internal wrongness begins.
character_journey.act_two: The curse activates. Strategic clarity begins to fracture. The agony cannot be reasoned away. Gallic instincts surface with increasing frequency.
character_journey.act_three: Death and curse activation. Rome becomes irrelevant. Strategy becomes compulsion. The perfectly calculated operative becomes a damned beast driven toward destruction.
character_journey.act_four: Second of the Arcani — more organized than Brutus, more calculating in approach to apocalypse. Encounters the spear. His strategic mind, now inverted, is the most dangerous of the four.

key_scenes: Book 1 — The Crucifixion: Plans and executes with strategic precision. Notes Malchus. Notes Brutus' unease. Curse begins.
Book 1 End: Something is wrong. Strategic frameworks cannot contain the wrongness.
Book 2: Agony intensifies. Gallic instincts surface dangerously. Ambition becomes secondary to survival.
Book 3 End: Death. Curse activation complete. Second Horseman emerges.

internal_conflicts.central_paradox: A man who constructed his entire identity through strategic choice — choosing Rome, choosing to bury Gaul, choosing advancement — is judged by a power that operates entirely outside strategic logic. His tools are useless. His superiority is the measure of his guilt.
internal_conflicts.why_it_matters: He chose Rome with full awareness. Brutus was born into it; Corvus chose it. The curse treats this deliberate, strategic participation as more culpable, not less.
internal_conflicts.how_it_resolves: It does not. The strategy cannot find a solution. He is consumed.

skills_knowledge.primary_skills: Strategic planning and tactical analysis. Political and social maneuvering. Combat mastery. Command of complex operations.
skills_knowledge.secondary_skills: Diplomacy. Multiple languages (Latin, Greek, suppressed Gallic). Weapons mastery including concealed blade.
skills_knowledge.limitations: Cannot overcome curse through strategy — it operates outside logical frameworks. Suppressed Gallic heritage creates dangerous instability under extreme pressure.
skills_knowledge.official_power: Centurion, second-in-command to Brutus. Respected by superiors as the strategic mind of the most efficient command unit in Jerusalem.
skills_knowledge.informal_power: Intellectual reputation. The understanding — shared but unspoken — that the strategy comes from Corvus.

historical_context.relevant_events: Roman occupation of Judea, 30–40 CE. Romanization of Gallic peoples — historically documented and widespread. Roman military hierarchy under Pontius Pilate. Crucifixion as standard Roman execution.
historical_context.period_knowledge: Latin (fluent), Greek (competent), Gallic (native, suppressed). Roman military doctrine. Political mechanics of Roman provincial command.
historical_context.cultural_protocols: Romanized Gauls occupied a real and specific social position — accepted but never fully trusted, required to prove Roman identity constantly.
historical_context.religious_framework: Roman pagan — Mars and Jupiter, pragmatic observance. Religion as institutional tool, not genuine devotion. Some residual Gallic druidic knowledge, deeply suppressed.

story_integration.first_appearance: Book 1, Scene 1 — active from the beginning through the final scene
story_integration.key_chapters: The crucifixion (Book 1); observation of Brutus' destabilization (Book 1 end); his own curse manifesting (Book 2); death and transformation (Book 3 end)
story_integration.plot_function: Strategic architect of Rome's operations. The calculating mind behind Brutus' authority. After cursing, the most organized and therefore most dangerous of the four — his strategic capacity now inverted toward apocalypse.
story_integration.theme_connection: The danger of intellect without conscience. Identity suppression and its cost. Deliberate choice as the measure of culpability — he chose Rome with full awareness, making his participation more, not less, damning.

character.why_readers_care: Corvus represents the danger of intellect without conscience. His character demonstrates how strategic brilliance can be deployed toward evil with full awareness. Readers are drawn to his intelligence and competence, even as they sense the ambition beneath. His descent from calculated second-in-command to cursed operative shows how identity suppression and deliberate choice carry their own judgment.
character_questions_for_readers: Can intellect without conscience be more dangerous than brute force?
What is the cost of suppressing one's identity for advancement?
Does deliberate choice make participation more culpable?
What happens when the tools that built success become useless?
